clinical_study.brief_title: How do Super Lean Subjects Keep Resistant to Body Weight Gain?
clinical_study.official_title: The Investigation of Lifestyle and Genetics in Super Lean Subjects That Keep Them Resistant to Weight Gain

brief_summary.textblock: Obesity is the 5th leading cause of global death, and is major risk factors for many chronic diseases, such as type 2 diabetes, cardiovascular diseases, hypertension and cancer. Obesity is caused by an imbalance between energy intake and energy expenditure, and it is widely agreed to be a consequence of a gene by environment interaction. Although on average obesity rates are increasing, the shape of the distribution of adiposity is changing: it is becoming more right skewed. This is because there is a population of very lean subjects that has remained almost unchanged by the epidemic. The investigators have called these very lean individuals that are resistant to the epidemic and sustain a BMI < 18.5 kg/m2 'super lean' subjects. We have very little understanding of the lifestyles of these individuals and how they are able to maintain their super lean phenotype, and whether the basis of their leanness is primarily genetics.

detailed_description.textblock: In this study, the investigators will recruit a sample of 150 super lean healthy volunteers with a BMI >15 and < 18.5 kg/m2 aged 20-40 years, in parallel with an age matched group of 150 healthy subjects with a BMI ≥22 and < 25 kg/m2 as the control group. The investigators will screen out any individuals with eating disorders. In both groups, the investigators will study their lifestyles in particular focusing on their physical activity patterns and their food intake choices (monitored via food intake diaries and supported by metabolomics analyses of their urine to detect biomarkers of different food groups). Saliva samples will be collected for genotyping. The investigators will SNP genotype the individuals for 30 known polymorphic loci previously linked to obesity to establish if they have a particular genetic profile linked to their lean phenotype.

primary_outcome.measure: Height, waist and hip circumferences (cm) of participants in both control and superlean groups
primary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 2 years
primary_outcome.description: Height, waist and hip circumference will be measured on arrival.

primary_outcome.measure: Body composition of participants in both control and superlean groups
primary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 2 years
primary_outcome.description: Body composition will be measured using Body composition analyzer Tanita, following measurement of height. Only the individuals with BMI within the inclusion criteria will be included.

primary_outcome.measure: Spirometric measurements of participants in both control and superlean groups
primary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 2 years
primary_outcome.description: Spirometric measurements will be performed using ndd EasyONE device, to determine the amount of air a person's lungs can take and the speed of the air being expelled with forceful and maximal efforts.

primary_outcome.measure: Reactive hyperemia index (RHI) of participants in both control and superlean groups
primary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 2 years
primary_outcome.description: RHI will be measured using Endo-PAT2000 device to assess their coronary artery endothelial function. Blood pressure was also measured as a requirement for the measurement of RHI.

primary_outcome.measure: Physical activity levels of participants in both control and superlean groups
primary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 2 years
primary_outcome.description: Physical activity of the participants will be recorded using GT3X monitor for a consecutive of 7 days.

primary_outcome.measure: Biochemical measurements and SNP genotyping of participants in both control and superlean groups
primary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 2 years
primary_outcome.description: Biochemical measurements will be performed in a local hospital, while the whole blood samples will be collected for DNA extraction. DNA samples will be then SNP genotyped. The genes that are related to BMI and physical activity will be SNP genotyped and the differences between superlean group and the control group will be investigated.

primary_outcome.measure: Resting energy expenditure of participants in both control and superlean groups
primary_outcome.time_frame: Through study completion, an average of 2 years
primary_outcome.description: The measurement of resting energy expenditure will be performed using indirect calorimetry. It will provide the information if the superlean people burn more energy at rest than the normal BMI group people.

arm_group.description: 20 kg/m2 ≤ BMI ≤ 25 kg/m2, healthy, with no eating disorder, 150 subjects, 20 - 40 years old
15 kg/m2 ≤ BMI ≤ 18 kg/m2, healthy, with no eating disorder, 150 subjects, 25 - 35 years old in particular

intervention.description: Behavioural data will be collected on all subjects in either control group or superlean group. Blood or saliva samples will be collected for DNA extraction and genotyping.

biospec_descr.textblock: 9 ml of blood samples will be collected for the biological measurements and DNA extraction for genotyping.

study_pop.textblock: Participants are healthy, with no eating disorder, 25 - 35 years old in particular.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- control: BMI 20-25 kg/m2, healthy, age 20-40 years old superlean: BMI 15-18 kg/m2, healthy, with no eating disorders and diabetes, age 20-40 years old
Exclusion Criteria:
- Pregnant women and women in lactation Subjects are suffering from eating disorders or diabetes.
